newsitem.title: USA: Duff & Phelps affirms Long Island Lighting ratings.
newsitem.headline: Duff & Phelps affirms Long Island Lighting ratings.

text.p: Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Co said Monday it reaffirmed Long Island Lighting Co's ratings, but may still change the utility's ratings following LILCO's announcement it signed a definitive agreement to merge with Brooklyn Union Gas Co.
Duff rates LILCO's general and refunding bonds as triple-B, debentures and unsecured/supported authority financing notes double-B-plus and preferred stock double-B.
Duff said LILCO is on "rating watch--uncertain."

Duff said the proposed tax-free transaction would result in a new holding company with LILCO and Brooklyn Union as its two primary subsidiaries. The fixed-income securities of each company would remain in place.
Duff said it continues to view LILCO's credit quality as highly dependent on a "credible, sustainable and politically workable resolution" to the problems of high electric rates on Long Island.
It added the merger with Brooklyn Union would help LILCO to lower modestly rates on Long Island through merger-related cost savings.

In order to achieve double-digit rate reductions, the sale of a significant portion of LILCO's assets to the Long Island Power Authority would be necessary so that the authority could refinance those assets on a tax-advantaged basis.

Regarding its current ratings, LILCO has weak credit protection measures and extremely high rates, Duff said. LILCO's asset and franchise values related to the electric transmission and distribution and local gas distribution businesses adequately secure the general and refunding bonds.
Dependence on regulatory and deferred assets makes the quality of other fixed-income obligations considerably weaker, Duff said.
